1528148704_1rFttYwcvZTeYwTHDHC5iy5PsfwHh.body:
sounds like you forgot to add permissions for yourself

Add permission yourself to read the auth cookie by usermod -a -G debian-tor [yourlinuxuser]
(if you are not on Debian check the file's user group by ls -al /var/run/tor/control.authcookie)

Bullet #5:
http://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-make-zeronet-work-with-tor-under-linux

1528171357_1rFttYwcvZTeYwTHDHC5iy5PsfwHh.body: Such an addition would vastly increase the resilience of Zeronet.

1528345024_1rFttYwcvZTeYwTHDHC5iy5PsfwHh.body:
Users should have some responsibility of being self aware of their environment. If a user on the clear net decided to go venture to a farm porn site and their computers get eaten alive by malware and browser hijacks, often spectators would blame the visitor for not taking proper precautionary measures of browsing a network blindly.

Most Zeronet sites are moderated quite well and any questionable content is removed if not avoided entirely from being uploaded. I've been an avid user of zeronet for a while now and I have yet to run across any CP. (But then again I don't go looking for it and avoid sites that may contain it like 0chan (due to rumors)).

There are plans of implementing a global multi-purpose blocklist with different categories that users will be able to subscribe to. But that seems to be reserved for a future development.

1528751326_1Jhso1pp8VNBQJBFuU7AjKC6NYdxs.body: Should it be considered data hoarding if anything lost can just be reacquired from file-sharing networks? It seems more like network storage redundancy.

1516184122_1J6csQA9K9NZaYUiCG5C2XQRF85yB.body:
In Namecoin Core, The [FIRSTUPDATE] will not occur until the NEW_NAME reaches 12 blocks. Once that has finished the Data of the FIRSTUPDATE will be processed. Until that time, accessing said address will not operate.

The format in the original post appears correct, here is the longer version for those who may want it

```
{
    "name": {"formatted": "ZeroVoat.bit"},
    "bitcoin": {"address": ""},
    "zeronet": {"": "1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb"},
    "ns": ["ns1.domaincoin.net", "ns2.domaincoin.net"]
}
```

1530089348_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5.body:
Children should be given the skills to remain private in their digital future. Of course such skill sets go against the collection of big data for personal use.

Responsible digital networking does not seem to be on the education's agenda for neither parent nor child. 

Of course parents have some responsibility knowing what places their child visits on the internet, but as explained prior, such skill sets have been deemed detrimental to big interests so it is often a skill that neither party practices.
